repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes #5088

TODO:
- [x] implement support of per-file compiler directives
- [x] tests
- [x] documentation

comment_data.body:
I don't understand one point - and it needs to be fixed somehow. `s.context.compiler_directives` does not contain comment compiler directives only argument-ones - So this is enabling legacy noexcept behaviour:
```
cython -X noexcept=True
```
But compiling following file not:
```
# cython: noexcept=True
...
```

I am not sure if it is a bug or it is done intentionally - the compiler directives are parsed in the beginning of parsing but are not put to context (they are present in later stages via `env.directives` dictionary):

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/b2015596b38df4b7b2978d87385da20d69e4e822/Cython/Compiler/Parsing.py#L3901-L3923

Could someone help me out with this issue? I am not sure what is the best/right approach...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3120,6 +3120,9 @@ def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
                 exc_check = False
             # exc_val can be non-None even if exc_check is False, c.f. "except -1"
             exc_val = p_test(s)
+    if not exc_clause and ctx.visibility  != 'extern' and s.context.compiler_directives.get('noexcept', False):

comment_data.body: Options.py also has a place where you set where directives can be applied (`directive_scopes`). I think `noexcept` should be `module` only.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -189,6 +189,7 @@ def copy_inherited_directives(outer_directives, **new_directives):
     'cdivision_warnings': False,
     'c_api_binop_methods': False,  # was True before 3.0
     'overflowcheck': False,
+    'noexcept': False,

comment_data.body:
I think the `compiler_directives` set on the `context` are just a way of passing them in on the command-line. They're only used as a way of feeding directives into Cython, so there's no point in updating it with directives from the comments.

In this case I think I'd follow what happens for `language_level` - put it as an attribute on the context.

I sort of think that the parser is the wrong place to be applying this and maybe we pass what's written to the nodes, and work out what it means later. But for now the simplest solution is probably to use an attribute on the context.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3120,6 +3120,9 @@ def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
                 exc_check = False
             # exc_val can be non-None even if exc_check is False, c.f. "except -1"
             exc_val = p_test(s)
+    if not exc_clause and ctx.visibility  != 'extern' and s.context.compiler_directives.get('noexcept', False):

comment_data.body:
> I sort of think that the parser is the wrong place to be applying this and maybe we pass what's written to the nodes

I was thinking about it but I personally don't like it because:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/b2015596b38df4b7b2978d87385da20d69e4e822/Cython/Compiler/Parsing.py#L3066-L3080

You need information if exception clause is present to decide between case `except *` and `<nothing> (default func.)`. This information is not present in `CFuncDeclaratorNode`:

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/b2015596b38df4b7b2978d87385da20d69e4e822/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L628-L644

I can add it there but I think information about exception clause is parser related and it should not go to the nodes.

comment_data.body: It might be easier to pick it out of `compiler_directives` in `Context.__init__` rather that having it as both a compiler directive and an option, and passing it as an argument to the constructor.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -61,16 +61,17 @@ class Context(object):
     #  the root of the module import namespace and the list
     #  of directories to search for include files.
     #
-    #  modules               {string : ModuleScope}
-    #  include_directories   [string]
-    #  future_directives     [object]
-    #  language_level        int     currently 2 or 3 for Python 2/3
+    #  modules                  {string : ModuleScope}
+    #  include_directories      [string]
+    #  future_directives        [object]
+    #  language_level           int     currently 2 or 3 for Python 2/3
+    #  legacy_implicit_noexcept [bool]
 
     cython_scope = None
     language_level = None  # warn when not set but default to Py2
 
     def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
-                 language_level=None, options=None):
+                 language_level=None, legacy_implicit_noexcept=None, options=None):

comment_data.body: I am not native english speaker so I can be cumbersome. I would like to somehow discourage users using this directive at all. Can we mention somehow that this directive is just for migration. I was thinking about mentioning that this directive is temporary for migration purposes and will be removed in the future?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -953,12 +953,18 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     Copy the original source code line by line into C code comments in the generated
     code file to help with understanding the output.
     This is also required for coverage analysis.
-    
+
 ``cpp_locals`` (True / False)
     Make C++ variables behave more like Python variables by allowing them to be
     "unbound" instead of always default-constructing them at the start of a
     function.  See :ref:`cpp_locals directive` for more detail.
 
+``legacy_implicit_noexcept`` (True / False)

comment_data.body:
Since it already raises a deprecation warning, I think this statement could be strengthened:
```suggestion
    cause Cython to have same semantics as Cython 0.2X. This directive is deprecated and
    exists solely to help migrate legacy code written before Cython 3.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -953,12 +953,19 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     Copy the original source code line by line into C code comments in the generated
     code file to help with understanding the output.
     This is also required for coverage analysis.
-    
+
 ``cpp_locals`` (True / False)
     Make C++ variables behave more like Python variables by allowing them to be
     "unbound" instead of always default-constructing them at the start of a
     function.  See :ref:`cpp_locals directive` for more detail.
 
+``legacy_implicit_noexcept`` (True / False)
+    When enabled, ``cdef`` functions will not propagate raised exceptions by default. Hence,
+    the function will behave same way as if declared with `noexcept` keyword. See
+    :ref:`error_return_values` for details. Setting this directive to ``True`` will
+    cause Cython to have same semantics as Cython 0.2X. This directive is intended to help
+    migrate legacy code written before Cython 3. We recommend leaving it off for new code.

comment_data.body: Might be good to do like https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/77918c57b5f36bee708f625e2499bf05b23a87f1/tests/run/nogil.pyx#L93 and test the "exception ignored" output
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,39 @@
+# cython: legacy_implicit_noexcept=True
+# mode: run
+# tag: warnings
+
+cdef int func_implicit(int a, int b):
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_noexcept(int a, int b) noexcept:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_star(int a, int b) except *:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+def test_noexcept():
+    """
+    >>> test_noexcept()
+    """
+    func_noexcept(3, 5)

comment_data.body:
A few possibly missing tests:

* `except -1` or similar test? I think it should work, but it's an obvious omission.
* return `object` (or don't specify the return). Given that this behaviour remains the same it possibly shouldn't be a warning.
* function pointers? I think they remain the same?
* `@cython.cfunc` - not quite sure what they do but it should probably be tested
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_star(int a, int b) except *:
+    raise RuntimeError
+

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
.. note::
  The unsafe legacy behaviour of not propagating exceptions by default can be enabled by
  setting ``legacy_implicit_noexcept`` :ref:`compiler directive<compiler-directives>`
  to ``True``.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -210,6 +210,12 @@ The behaviour for any ``cdef`` function that is declared with an
 explicit exception value (e.g., ``cdef int spam(int x) except -1``) is
 also unchanged.
 
+.. note::
+  The legacy semantics of not propagating exceptions by default can be enabled by
+  setting ``legacy_implicit_noexcept`` :ref:`compiler directive<compiler-directives>`
+  to ``True``.

comment_data.body: I agree that it's not worth passing it around as call arguments.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    cause Cython 3.0 to have the same semantics as Cython 0.x. This directive was solely added
    to help migrate legacy code written before Cython 3. It will be removed in a future release.
```

comment_data.body: I only saw this part of the discussion now. I think it's ok to tell users that it will eventually be removed. That's what "deprecation" means, really. We may find a wording that keeps them from perpetually asking "are we there yet", though.

comment_data.body:
The more interesting case is probably `@cython.cfunc @cython.returns(int)` where the behaviour might be different. I'm not sure off the top of my head what the 0.29.x and current master behaviour is though. But I have a feeling we might not be dealing with this right.

If we aren't dealing with it right then this PR probably isn't the place to do it though.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,138 @@
+# cython: legacy_implicit_noexcept=True
+# mode: run
+# tag: warnings
+import cython
+try:
+    from StringIO import StringIO
+except ImportError:
+    from io import StringIO
+
+cdef int func_implicit(int a, int b):
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_noexcept(int a, int b) noexcept:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_star(int a, int b) except *:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_value(int a, int b) except -1:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef func_return_obj_implicit(int a, int b):
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int(*ptr_func_implicit)(int, int)
+ptr_func_implicit = func_implicit
+
+cdef int(*ptr_func_noexcept)(int, int) noexcept
+ptr_func_noexcept = func_noexcept
+
+@cython.cfunc
+def pure_func_implicit():
+    raise RuntimeError

comment_data.body: Eh I missed to return cython.int. You are explicitely interesed in explicitely in decorator `@cython.returns(int)` or just for case returning int? (`-> cython.int`)

+    from io import StringIO
+
+cdef int func_implicit(int a, int b):
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_noexcept(int a, int b) noexcept:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_star(int a, int b) except *:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_value(int a, int b) except -1:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef func_return_obj_implicit(int a, int b):
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int(*ptr_func_implicit)(int, int)
+ptr_func_implicit = func_implicit
+
+cdef int(*ptr_func_noexcept)(int, int) noexcept
+ptr_func_noexcept = func_noexcept
+
+@cython.cfunc
+def pure_func_implicit():
+    raise RuntimeError

comment_data.body:
> Just the case returning a C integer. So using the `->` syntax is probably better.

OK unittest updated with returning int. BTW. in 0.29 the semantics is that it propagates exception by default:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/827060/197889866-53a75b34-1349-4f22-afc1-ba30b437c7cf.png)

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -61,16 +61,17 @@ class Context(object):
     #  the root of the module import namespace and the list
     #  of directories to search for include files.
     #
-    #  modules               {string : ModuleScope}
-    #  include_directories   [string]
-    #  future_directives     [object]
-    #  language_level        int     currently 2 or 3 for Python 2/3
+    #  modules                  {string : ModuleScope}
+    #  include_directories      [string]
+    #  future_directives        [object]
+    #  language_level           int     currently 2 or 3 for Python 2/3
+    #  legacy_implicit_noexcept [bool]
 
     cython_scope = None
     language_level = None  # warn when not set but default to Py2
 
     def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
-                 language_level=None, options=None):
+                 language_level=None, legacy_implicit_noexcept=None, options=None):

comment_data.body:
Is the `getattr()` only needed for the `None` case? If so, I'd change it to be more explicit:
```suggestion
        self.legacy_implicit_noexcept = options.legacy_implicit_noexcept if options else False
```
The `getattr()` suggests to me that there are cases where the option might not be initialised, in which case I'd rather see it being initialised.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -91,6 +91,8 @@ def __init__(self, include_directories, compiler_directives, cpp=False,
         if language_level is not None:
             self.set_language_level(language_level)
 
+        self.legacy_implicit_noexcept = getattr(options, 'legacy_implicit_noexcept', False)

comment_data.body: Doesn't this also hit the case where `legacy_implicit_noexcept=False`? I mean, it's certainly ok to overwrite it with a `False` default directives value in that case, but then we're assuming here that both default values actually are False. The code here probably shouldn't depend on that. Maybe we could use `None` for the default value instead of `False`, and test that here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+        if 'legacy_implicit_noexcept' in directives and 'legacy_implicit_noexcept' not in kw:
+            options['legacy_implicit_noexcept'] = directives['legacy_implicit_noexcept']
+        elif not options.get('legacy_implicit_noexcept'):

@@ -953,12 +953,19 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     Copy the original source code line by line into C code comments in the generated
     code file to help with understanding the output.
     This is also required for coverage analysis.
-    
+
 ``cpp_locals`` (True / False)
     Make C++ variables behave more like Python variables by allowing them to be
     "unbound" instead of always default-constructing them at the start of a
     function.  See :ref:`cpp_locals directive` for more detail.
 
+``legacy_implicit_noexcept`` (True / False)
+    When enabled, ``cdef`` functions will not propagate raised exceptions by default. Hence,
+    the function will behave same way as if declared with `noexcept` keyword. See

@@ -0,0 +1,164 @@
+# cython: legacy_implicit_noexcept=True
+# mode: run
+# tag: warnings
+import cython
+try:
+    from StringIO import StringIO
+except ImportError:
+    from io import StringIO
+
+cdef int func_implicit(int a, int b):
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_noexcept(int a, int b) noexcept:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_star(int a, int b) except *:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int func_value(int a, int b) except -1:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef func_return_obj_implicit(int a, int b):
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+cdef int(*ptr_func_implicit)(int, int)
+ptr_func_implicit = func_implicit
+
+cdef int(*ptr_func_noexcept)(int, int) noexcept
+ptr_func_noexcept = func_noexcept
+
+@cython.cfunc
+def func_pure_implicit() -> cython.int:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+@cython.excetval(check=False)
+@cython.cfunc
+def func_pure_noexcept() -> cython.int:
+    raise RuntimeError
+
+def test_noexcept():
+    """
+    >>> print(test_noexcept())  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
+    RuntimeError
+    Exception...ignored...
+    """
+    import sys
+    old_stderr = sys.stderr
+    stderr = sys.stderr = StringIO()
+    try:
+        func_noexcept(3, 5)
+    finally:
+        sys.stderr = old_stderr
+    return stderr.getvalue().strip()

comment_data.body: Just to note - a lot of this goes away if we keep it out of `options` and just extract it from `compiler_directives` in `Context.__init__`

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
By default Cython uses a dedicated return value to signal that an exception has been raised from non-external ``cpdef``/``@ccall``
functions. However, how Cython handles exceptions from these functions can be changed if needed.
```
Small re-write...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -655,8 +655,8 @@ error return value.
 While this is always the case for Python functions, functions
 defined as C functions or ``cpdef``/``@ccall`` functions can return arbitrary C types,
 which do not have such a well-defined error return value.
-Extra care must be taken to ensure Python exceptions are correctly
-propagated from such functions.
+Cython by default uses dedicated value to propagate exceptions from a non-external ``cpdef``/``@ccall``
+functions. Moreover, the way how an exception is propagated can be changed if needed.

comment_data.body: :-/ wrong branch. I have another PR for docs. Should I move it there or can it stay here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -655,8 +655,8 @@ error return value.
 While this is always the case for Python functions, functions
 defined as C functions or ``cpdef``/``@ccall`` functions can return arbitrary C types,
 which do not have such a well-defined error return value.
-Extra care must be taken to ensure Python exceptions are correctly
-propagated from such functions.
+Cython by default uses dedicated value to propagate exceptions from a non-external ``cpdef``/``@ccall``
+functions. Moreover, the way how an exception is propagated can be changed if needed.

commit.message: Set directive scope to noexcept as module
Implemented per-file legacy_implicit_noexcept directive, improved directive name and warning message
Mention new directive in porting guide

Add tests for setup.py based build
Update Error return values section in language basics

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Add compiler directive to disable the default exception propagation
